stream_context.summary: Kaze block-ed-out and iterated on the underground section of the Oil-Rig course (Course 11).  He placed two remaining Yoshi-coin challenges (an oil-cleaning shell puzzle and a slide jump), routed three surface entrances into a shared cavern, added a glass-walled grate overlooking the exterior, chose provisional metal textures/grates and tweaked difficulty of a key jump.  Throughout the stream he discussed engine optimisations, asset guidelines and team hand-offs.

development_findings.summary: Only two areas remain in the Oil-Rig level; both Yoshi-coin challenges (shell-cleaning an oil spot and a slide into a crevice) were planned and placed in the underground section.
development_findings.quote: "One Yoshi coin is going to be cleaning up another oil spot right here with a shell… the other one is gonna be sliding down the slide and jumping into this crevice."

development_findings.summary: Underground layout now links three separate surface entrances, each landing at different heights near a suspended grate window so players can see the rig exterior.
development_findings.quote: "One entrance here, one entrance here and one entrance here and they all connect underground through this thing here."

development_findings.summary: Decided to use a glass material for a large window-grate to reinforce the industrial theme and let players glimpse platforms above.
development_findings.quote: "What if all of this was like the reinforced window… this is just gonna be transparent material."

development_findings.summary: Settled on heavy-metal / oil aesthetic but is still searching for fitting textures; artists will refine in post.
development_findings.quote: "Big pipes and shit, heavy metal, leaking water… I definitely want oil."

development_findings.summary: Surface-sound system finished; Yoshi Milkman produced new footstep SFX for wood, steel, glass, leaves, meat and grates.
development_findings.quote: "Listen closely… Surface sounds made by Yoshi Milkman… he put a lot of work into making this perfect."

development_findings.summary: Engine optimisation video angle: freeing RAM & CPU gives ‘more freedom for artists’; optimisation is used as marketing talking point.
development_findings.quote: "Look, with all this optimisation artists have so much more freedom and we brought more artists on board."

development_findings.summary: Prefers hard-coding rare special behaviours via one open parameter rather than building a full generic system.
development_findings.quote: "I can hard-code because it is so rare that I want a special behavior like that."

development_findings.summary: Loading system now decompresses data and waits 8 frames (versus Nintendo’s original 16-frame fake delay) so real load time stays invisible.
development_findings.quote: "Mario 64’s loading times are so fast that they put an artificial 16 frame delay… we just wait 8 frames."

development_findings.summary: XZ/LZMA decompression is desired but not yet integrated; lacks profile code.
development_findings.quote: "The problem with XZ decompression is that I don't have the code for it, so I couldn't profile it yet."

development_findings.summary: Requested a new ‘oil Frizzlet’ enemy: ~150 polys, CI/I texture 64×64, moves like electric Frizzlet but leaves damaging oil puddles.
development_findings.quote: "I want something like that, but made out of oil… That’s a random asset I need."

development_findings.summary: Difficulty philosophy: keeps Course 11 challenging but avoids harsh punishment; continues to lower overall hack difficulty due to community feedback.

context_findings.summary: Kaze emigrated from Germany to Canada to avoid high taxes and prefers Canadian cost-of-living; discusses economics and tipping culture.
context_findings.quote: "I'm glad I moved to Canada instead of staying in Germany – I would be taxed so much money."

context_findings.summary: Surprised and pleased by YouTube growth; each new video outperforms the last.
context_findings.quote: "Every video is doing better than the previous one – my YouTube channel is on an upwards draft."

context_findings.summary: Holds utilitarian view on morality: acts ‘good’ mainly to avoid cancellation or reputational loss.
context_findings.quote: "It makes a lot of sense to always act moral, even if I don't believe in morality, simply because I would get cancelled."

context_findings.summary: Strives for work-life balance; ends stream to spend evening with spouse Zeina.
Expresses analytical worldview (game theory, Nash equilibrium) even in everyday scenarios (e.g., tipping, hostage metaphors).

biobak.summary: Gave critical feedback on prop textures and agreed to polish underground materials/skybox; Kaze will leave exact details to him.
biobak.quote: "The texture work and props leave a lot to be desired… I'll leave the exact details to you."

badub.summary: Composed a track for the Buzzard/Bowser 2 fight and is scoring the upcoming Oil Boss theme.
badub.quote: "Badub made a song for it… also making a song for the oil boss that's fit to the cut-scene."

zeina.summary: Offered to create monkey animations and participated in live design chat; personal dynamic shown when Kaze ends stream to go out with her.

key_stories.title: Building the Underground Oil-Rig
key_stories.summary: Course 11 needed its final two Yoshi-coin challenges and a connective layout.  Kaze mapped three entrances, designed a slide route, a shell-cleanup puzzle, and introduced a glass window grate to expose the outside environment.
key_stories.challenge: The level still lacked a coherent underground section and two collectible challenges.
key_stories.process: Live grey-boxed geometry, debated textures and jump difficulty, solicited feedback from Biobak and chat, and integrated new materials and platform types.
key_stories.outcome: Functional layout with coin goals, slide path, shell spot, entrances and provisional textures is in place; artists will refine visuals.
key_stories.key_quote: "We have one entrance here, one entrance here… underground we need two Yoshi coins and the 8-bit pipe – that’s what we’re working on today."

key_stories.title: Optimisation as Creative Enabler
key_stories.summary: Kaze plans a YouTube video arguing that recent engine optimisations unlock artistic freedom and have allowed more contributors to join RTYI.
key_stories.challenge: Historic N64 limits and public perception that large teams can’t work on a ROM-hack.
key_stories.process: Profiled code, reduced memory/CPU load; framed narrative for upcoming video; highlighted new SFX and artwork now possible.
key_stories.outcome: Video draft underway; team expansion (e.g., Biobak graphics, additional music) cited as proof.
key_stories.key_quote: "With all this optimisation artists have so much more freedom and we brought more artists on board… that’s gonna be the angle."

key_stories.title: DoorDash Fish-Food Fiasco
key_stories.summary: Kaze ordered aquarium supplies via DoorDash, selected $0 delivery and no tip; only half the order arrived, sparking a debate on tipping and ‘hostage’ economics.
key_stories.challenge: Missing items after choosing not to tip.
key_stories.process: Discussed tipping culture, compared to hostage negotiation using Nash equilibrium logic.
key_stories.outcome: No immediate solution; highlighted Kaze’s analytical worldview and Canadian context.
key_stories.key_quote: "They got my order wrong – I am so glad I didn’t tip… why would I pay $12 if the item costs $10?"

open_questions.context: Kaze requested an oil version of the Frizzlet with 150-poly budget and 64×64 texture but no one assigned yet.
questions: What behaviour variations (speed, damage, animation) does Kaze envision beyond the existing Frizzlet?
Who is responsible for modelling, rigging and coding this enemy?
How will the oil puddle graphic and collision be implemented on N64 hardware?

open_questions.context: Kaze likes the idea of ‘boiling oil’ but is unsure how to realise it on N64.
questions: What shader or sprite technique will simulate boiling oil within hardware limits?
Is the effect reserved for gameplay hazards or purely decorative?

open_questions.context: Kaze wants faster compression but lacks code to profile XZ.
questions: Is anyone on the team investigating alternative decompression libraries?
What memory and CPU budget is available for a heavier algorithm?
Would faster loading free space for additional art/audio?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated four courses and some side levels remain but no timeline.
questions: What is the current milestone schedule for completing remaining courses?
Is there an internal beta or public demo planned?
How will marketing (trailers, Directs) be handled given Nintendo sensitivities?

open_questions.context: Kaze admitted he ‘doesn’t know what the theme is’ beyond industrial pipes.
questions: Has a final concept art pass been approved?
Will narrative or environmental storytelling explain the area?
What reference material or mood boards does Biobak need?
